newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ dollar closes firmer despite negative poll.
newsitem.headline: NZ dollar closes firmer despite negative poll.

text.p: The New Zealand dollar closed firmer on Friday despite an opinion poll published which was negative for the ruling conservative National Party.
Dealers said the market was underpinned by a succession of eurokiwi issues and this was more likely to set the tone for the currency than political sentiment.
The Kiwi ended at US$0.6914/21 at 5.00 pm (0500 GMT), against its 0.6907/14 close while the Trade-Weighted Index closed exactly on its opening at 65.49.
Dealers estimate there is around NZ$600 million of kiwi to be bought for settlement between September 11-17 and they anticipate buying ahead of that will underpin the Kiwi.
Some interbank players attempted to get short after the National Business Review poll showed National party support falling three points to 34 percent. A general election will be held on October 12.
Dealers said there was a high degree of scepticism about the poll and traders squaring up at the end of the session were partly responsible for the firm tone at the close.
There was little exporter interest with most flows capital based, dealers said.

Dealers will be watching the Australian dollar which was close to a triple top at US$0.7930. A failure to penetrate that level could see some technical selling of the Kiwi which could feed demand for further eurokiwi issues.
